description: In Liberia, the Ministry of Education has ordered for all schools nationwide, including universities, to suspend classes for one week starting from Tuesday, March 17.  Indeed, soon after schools across Liberia closed on March 16, when the country's first coronavirus case was confirmed, authorities launched a radio schooling initiative to bridge an education gap.  Within two weeks, the first lessons were aired on radio stations nationwide. Today, some 32 stations now broadcast several prerecorded lessons a day, each lasting half an hour, catering to different educational levels.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: "On March 22, the Liberian Ministry of Health released a Declaration of National Health Emergency." The Declaration announces school closures and restrictions on public gatherings in Monteserrado and Margibi counties, as well as the closure of Roberts International Airport (with limited exceptions).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Liberia's President George Weah announces that he intends to declare a state of emergency starting at 23:59 (local time) on Friday, April 10, due to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. President Weah has called for an emergency session of parliament so that MPs can approve the measure. The emergency law would last for three weeks and is renewable. Throughout this period, residents may only leave home for essential journeys such as food shopping and for medical purposes, which should be restricted to local communities and be limited to a single person per household for a maximum of one hour.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Liberia's President George Weah announced that he intends to declare a state of emergency starting at 23:59 (local time) on Friday, April 10, due to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. President Weah has called for an emergency session of parliament so that MPs can approve the measure. The emergency law would last for three weeks and is renewable.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: President George Weah announced that Liberia's stay-at-home measures in place to prevent the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) will be extended by a further two weeks through until Friday, May 8. The measures have been in place since Saturday, April 11, and will now include the compulsory wearing of face masks in public. Among other restrictions remaining in effect is a daily curfew at 15:00 (local time), a ban on movement between counties, and the closure of all non-essential businesses.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Liberia's President George Weah announced that he intends to declare a state of emergency starting at 23:59 (local time) on Friday, April 10, due to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. President Weah has called for an emergency session of parliament so that MPs can approve the measure. The emergency law would last for three weeks and is renewable. Throughout this period, residents may only leave home for essential journeys such as food shopping and for medical purposes, which should be restricted to local communities and be limited to a single person per household for a maximum of one hour. UPDATE: The original quarantine was set to last until May 8th, has been extended to another 2 weeks, ending May 22nd
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: "On March 22, the Liberian Ministry of Health released a Declaration of National Health Emergency." The Declaration announces school closures and restrictions on public gatherings in Monteserrado and Margibi counties, as well as the closure of Roberts International Airport (with limited exceptions). On May 17th, Liberia is reopening its houses of worship. UPDATE: In Liberia, Mosques/Religious Worship Centers that were closed since March 22, have been reopened starting May 17th, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Liberia's President George Weah announced that he intends to declare a state of emergency starting at 23:59 (local time) on Friday, April 10, due to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. President Weah has called for an emergency session of parliament so that MPs can approve the measure. The emergency law would last for three weeks and is renewable. Throughout this period, residents may only leave home for essential journeys such as food shopping and for medical purposes, which should be restricted to local communities and be limited to a single person per household for a maximum of one hour. description: Liberia's President George Weah announced that he intends to declare a state of emergency starting at 23:59 (local time) on Friday, April 10, due to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. President Weah has called for an emergency session of parliament so that MPs can approve the measure. The emergency law would last for three weeks and is renewable. UPDATE: Liberian President George Weah announced that the state of emergency would end 9 June 2020. Justice Minister Frank Musa Dean said this was an error and that the 60 day state of emergency will end 21 June 2021.

description: On Monday, June 22 2020, authorities in Liberia announced that the reopening of Roberts International Airport (ROB) in Monrovia, previously expected to reopen on Sunday, June 21, has been delayed until Sunday, June 28. Borders are to remain closed and travel between regions is banned.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban
target_geog_level: All countries

description: With the resumption of commercial flight operations at Roberts International Airport (RIA) on June 28, the Ministry of Information, Culture, and Tourism announced the following health measures and protocols for arriving passengers: All passengers will be required to have their temperature taken for symptoms of COVID-19 and register via phone numbers/USSD Mobile App. All arriving passengers who have been tested at point of departure must present a valid negative result document on arrival at RIA. All arriving passengers who have not been tested at point of departure will be required to take a rapid test and a PCR swab at airport. In the event of a positive rapid test result, the passenger will be placed in the holding unit at the airport pending the final PCR test result. Passengers having negative test results will be allowed to go home pending final PCR test. There will be continued symptom monitoring via USSD and Mobile App.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The travelers’ protocols, released on Monday, November 23, 2020 by the Ministry of Health, makes it mandatory for all travelers to complete a symptom tracker form and the payment of the US$75.00 testing fee. The new Travelers protocols also require that the National Public Health Reference Lab tests all non- exempt travelers for COVID-19. Exempt travelers who do not have a valid negative COVID-19 test result will also be tested .The Ministry of Health says travelers who test PCR positive for COVID-19 will undergo treatment based on Liberia case management guidelines while travelers who test negative are to self-quarantine and monitor their symptoms via the Liberia Travel App for a period of 14 days, beginning the day after their arrival in Liberia.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: The Liberian Ministry of Health updated its Traveler’s Protocol dated 20 July 2022. Effective immediately, no COVID test is required to enter Liberia and all COVID-19 testing for incoming travelers is suspended. However, all travelers aged 18 and over must show proof of vaccination upon arrival. Those without proof of vaccination will be returned to their country of embarkation at the traveler’s or airline’s expense. Incoming passengers are no longer required to complete the Health Screening Arrival Form.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Proof of COVID-19 vaccination
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry)
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: Following the reopening of Monrovia, Liberia, airport (21 June 2020) and the resumption of international flights, all passengers upon arrival in Liberia were required to submit a certificate of negativity after a PCR test carried out no more than 72 hours before the arrival.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: A snapshot of a person’s health at a given point in time
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Liberia ordered that "all passengers arriving at the country's airport be checked by a medical team, before border checks."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Liberian President George Weah announced on April 10, an emergency law that would last three weeks and is renewable. Throughout this period, residents may only leave home for essential journeys such as food shopping and for medical purposes, which should be restricted to local communities and be limited to a single person per household for a maximum of one hour.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 30th, Liberia reported that the Special Presidential Advisory Committee on COVID-19 (SPACO) was officially launched and chaired by
the President of the Republic of Liberia and through consultation with this Committee, will make decisions on appointments and strategies for operational and community-oriented outreach.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
Liberian President George Weah says the country has made enough progress against the coronavirus to allow the reopening of the international airport and hotels in two weeks' time.
A state of emergency which is due to end next Tuesday will not be renewed.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Liberian schools and communities raised awareness about COVID 19 through WASH campaigns sponsored by the National Red Cross Society starting March 13th.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: President George Weah announced that Liberia's stay-at-home measures in place to prevent the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) will be extended by a further two weeks through until Friday, May 8. The measures have been in place since Saturday, April 11, and will now include the compulsory wearing of face masks in public. Among other restrictions remaining in effect are a daily curfew at 15:00 (local time), a ban on movement between counties, and the closure of all non-essential businesses
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On June 17 Ministry of Health of Liberia announced that public offices are required to reduce staff by 50 percent, while others work from home. For violation of this guideline sanction not exceeding 200 USD or imprisonment not exceeding thirty days are considered.
